introduction.p:
In Activity, we investigated a degree 3 polynomial approximation T(x) to f(x) = e^x near a = 0. To do so, we chose the conditions T(0) = f(0), T'(0) = f'(0), T''(0) = f''(0), and T'''(0) = f'''(0). Starting with T(x) = k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k^3 x^3 and f(x) = e^x and finding the needed derivatives and evaluating them at a = 0 led us to the results in Table
Formulas and values for f(x) = e^x and T(x) = k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k_3 x^3.
f(x)= e^x T(x)= k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k_3 x^3
f'(x)= e^x T'(x)= k_1 + 2 k_2 x + 3 k_3 x^2
f''(x)= e^x T''(x)= 2 k_2 + 6 k_3 x
f''(x)= e^x T''(x)= 6 k_3
f(0)= 1 T(0)= k_0
f'(0)= 1 T'(0)= k_1
f''(0)= 1 T''(0)= 2k_2
f''(0)= 1 T''(0)= 6k_3

Equating the function and derivative values of f and T at a = 0, we found that k_0 = 1, k_1 = 1, 2k_2 = 1, 6k_3 = 1 and therefore k_0 = 1, k_1 = 1, k_2 = \frac{1}{2}, k_3 = \frac{1}{6} so that T(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6}x^3. Moreover, plotting f and T near a = 0, we see in the Figure that the interval of accuracy for a tolerance of 0.1 is about -1.2 \le x \le 1.2, where the approximation is slightly better to the left of a = 0 than to the right.
The function f(x)=e^x and its degree 3 Taylor approximation T(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6}x^3 near the point (0,f(0)).

More precisely, we might compute that |f(-1.16) - T(-1.16)| \approx 0.0608 and |f(1.16) - T(1.16)| \approx 0.0970 and |f(-1.16) - T(-1.16)| \approx 0.0608, which helps us see the degree 3 approximation is very accurate on an interval wider than |x| \lt 1.
In this section, we will see how we can find higher degree approximations for functions other than f(x) = e^x, as well as how to center the approximation at a value other than a = 0.

subsection.title: Taylor polynomials
subsection.p:
In our work so far in Chapter, we have found several different approximations of two important functions: e^x and \sin(x). In Section, we saw that near a = 0
e^x \approx 1 + x (the degree 1 approximation);
e^x \approx 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 (the degree 2 approximation); and
e^x \approx 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6}x^3 (the degree 3 approximation).
Moreover, we found that as the degree of the approximation increased, the polynomial approximation got more accurate by being closer to the e^x on a wider interval.

In Preview, we saw further that
\sin(x) \approx x (the degree 1 approximation); and
\sin(x) \approx x - \frac{1}{6}x^3 (the degree 3 approximation).

We can also notice that the linear approximation is embedded within the quadratic approximation, and the quadratic approximation within the cubic one, and so on. These observations naturally lead us to consider approximations of arbitrary degree n in order to generate more accurate approximations for any function with a sufficient number of derivatives. We thus define the Taylor polynomial of degree n centered at a = 0 as follows.

definition.statement: Let n be a natural number and let f be a function with at least n derivatives at a = 0. The degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a = 0 is the function T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1x + c_2x^2 + \cdots + c_nx^n that satisfies T_n(0) = f(0), T_n’(0) = f’(0), T_n’’(0) = f’’(0), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(0) = f^{(n)}(0).

subsection.p: By definition, T_n is the polynomial whose function and first n derivative values at a = 0 match the function value and all n derivative values of f at a = 0.

The n+1 equations T_n(0) = f(0), T_n’(0) = f’(0), T_n’’(0) = f’’(0), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(0) = f^{(n)}(0) enable us to determine the coefficients c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_n in terms of the values of the various derivatives of f. Indeed, by taking the various derivatives of T_n(x), evaluating those derivatives at a = 0, and setting each result equal to the corresponding derivative value of f, we see the results in the Table.

table.title: Finding the coefficients c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_n in a Taylor polynomial.

cell.m: T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1x + c_2x^2 + c_3x^3 + c_4x^4 + \cdots + c_nx^n
